title: 115_hr5270
content: The Act is titled the "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" and includes a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units under section 45T of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Electricity Reliability and Fuel Security Act" includes a Federal Tax Credit for Coal-Powered Electric Generation Units, where the credit is 30% of qualified expenses or $13 multiplied by the unit's capacity rating in kilowatts. A coal-powered electric generation unit is defined as an electric generation unit using coal. The term `coal-powered electric generation unit' refers to a unit using coal to produce at least 75% of its electricity. `Qualified expenses' are for operation or maintenance, excluding coal costs. Public entities can transfer the credit under certain conditions. The eligible project partner can elect to be treated as the taxpayer for a specified portion of the credit under subsection (a) for a taxable year, instead of the qualified public entity. The qualified public entity, defined as a government entity or certain electric companies, can be treated as the taxpayer for a portion of the credit. The eligible project partner for a coal-powered electric generation unit is defined as any person responsible for operating, maintaining, or repairing the unit. This applies to mutual or cooperative electric companies, not-for-profit electric utilities that received a loan under the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. The eligible project partner for a coal-powered electric generation unit is defined as any person responsible for operating, maintaining, or repairing the unit, participating in coal provision, providing financing, or leasing the unit. In partnerships, a qualified public entity is treated as the taxpayer for its share of the credit. Any partner of the partnership is considered an eligible project partner for the credit. In partnerships, a qualified public entity is treated as the taxpayer for its share of the credit. Any partner of the partnership is considered an eligible project partner for the credit. The credit is taken into account in the first taxable year of the eligible project partner ending with, or after, the qualified public entity's taxable year with respect to which the credit was determined. Any benefit derived by an eligible project partner in connection with a transfer is subject to private use rules. For section 141(b)(1), benefits from an election under this subsection are not considered private business use. A basis adjustment is made for coal-powered electric generation units when a credit is allowed. This section applies to taxable years from 2018 to 2022. Section 501(c)(12)(I) is amended accordingly. Beginning after December 31, 2017, and ending before January 1, 2023, a credit is allowed against the alternative minimum tax. Section 501(c)(12)(I) is amended to include the credit determined under section 45T. The credit determined under section 45T is added to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The credit for coal-powered electric generation units is determined under section 45T and added to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1.
